Applying the Apache License

When distributing your software under Apache Licence (or any licence) it is important to include the license header in all the source files (in general, all the human readable files in the source tree). This is to let the users know under which license the source is distributed. In addition, you must include
LICENSE and NOTICE files
in all the distributions that you deliver. LICENSE and NOTICE must always be tailored to the content of the specific distribution they reside within.
Add a licence header to all the source files

To apply the Apache License to your work, attach the
following boilerplate notice
. The text should be enclosed in the appropriate comment syntax for the file format.
Copyright 20xx-20xx Ontology Engineering Group, Universidad Politécnica de Madrid, Spain

   Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License");
   you may not use this file except in compliance with the License.
   You may obtain a copy of the License at

       http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0

   Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software
   distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
   WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
   See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
   limitations under the License.
Add a LICENCE file at the top of level of distributions

This file can be named as LICENCE.txt but the LICENCE
is preferred
.
Source Distribution

If your source distributions contain only the files that you have written and all of them are licensed under Apache License 2.0, LICENSE should only contain
the text of the Apache Licence v2
.
If your source distributions contain source files that are licensed under difference licenses, for example some example file from W3C working group or any source file that was contributed to you by someone under different license, In LICENSE file, add a pointer to the to the location within the source tree and a short note summarizing its licensing. A complete example can be found
here
.
By any chance if you source distribution bundles any third party libraries as binaries, the conditions in the following section apply equally to your source distribution too.
Binary Distribution

Binary distributions follow the same pattern as in the source distributions. However, in contrast to the source distribution binary distributions generally bundle third-party dependencies that are required for your software.
If your binary distribution only contains software you have developed, then LICENSE should only contain
the text of the Apache Licence v2
.
If you binary distribution bundles and redistribute third-party dependencies (which is the common case) that are under different but compatible license,
add a short note summarizing its licensing and a pointer to it's license
. Following example shows a LICENCE file of a product that bundles two third-party dependencies.
Apache License
                           Version 2.0, January 2004
                        http://www.apache.org/licenses/

   TERMS AND CONDITIONS FOR USE, REPRODUCTION, AND DISTRIBUTION

   1. Definitions.

      "License" shall mean the terms and conditions for use, reproduction,
      and distribution as defined by Sections 1 through 9 of this document.

  ... REST OF THE APACHE LICENCE REMOVED FOR BREVITY OF THE EXAMPLE ...

  END OF TERMS AND CONDITIONS

  --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  This software contains the D3.js Javascript library, which is available under a
  "New BSD" license.  Copyright (c) 2012, Michael Bostock.
  For details, see http://d3js.org/.

  This software contains unmodified binary redistributions of the Logback
  Core and Classic Module, which are available under Eclipse Public License
  (EPL 1.0). Copyright (c) 1999-2012 QOS.ch
  For details, see http://logback.qos.ch/
Add a NOTICE file at the top level of distributions

The NOTICE file is described in
section 4.4 of the Apache License version 2.0
. It presence is not mandated by the license itself, but it is considered as a good practice. Following is the
minimal boilerplate template
for the NOTICE file.
[PRODUCT_NAME]
Copyright [20xx-20xx] Ontology Engineering Group, Universidad Politécnica de Madrid, Spain

This product includes software developed at
the Ontology Engineering Group (http://www.oeg-upm.net/).
Source Distribution

Binary Distribution

Bundling a dependency which is issued under one of the following licenses is straightforward, assuming that said license applies uniformly to all files within the dependency. In LICENSE, add a
pointer
to the dependency's location within the source tree and a short note summarizing its licensing:
This product bundles SuperWidget 1.2.3, which is available under a
"3-clause BSD" license.  For details, see deps/superwidget/.

Tools that can help with software licenses

Apache Rat
- A release audit tool
maven-license-plugin
- Maven plugin to update and verify header licenses of source files
Eclipse Code Templates
- automatically adds the pre-configured license header to each new file [Window > Preferences > Java > Code Style > Code Templates > Comments > Files]
